definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To move or burst forth.
examples: The boat sprang a leak and began to sink.

subdefinitions.definition: To grow , to sprout. ( UK dialectal ) To mature.
( figurative ) To arise , to come into existence .

examples: He hit the gas and the car sprang to life .

subdefinitions.definition: ( figurative , usually with cardinal adverbs ) To move with great speed and energy .
examples: Deer spring with their hind legs, using their front hooves to steady themselves.

subdefinitions.definition: ( usually with from ) To be born , descend , or originate from
( obsolete ) To rise in social position or military rank , to be promoted .

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To cause to spring (all senses).

subdefinitions.definition: ( of mechanisms ) To cause to work or open by sudden application of pressure .

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To leap over.
( obsolete , of horses ) To breed with, to impregnate .
( transitive , obsolete ) To wet , to moisten .
( intransitive , now usually with "apart" or "open" ) To burst into pieces , to explode , to shatter .
( obsolete , military ) To go off .
( ambitransitive , nautical , usually perfective ) To crack .
To come upon and flush out .
( Australia , slang ) To catch in an illegal act or compromising position .
( obsolete ) To begin .
( obsolete , slang ) To put bad money into circulation .
To tell , to share .
examples: Sorry to spring it on you like this but I've been offered another job.

definitions.definition: ( transitive , slang , US ) To free from imprisonment , especially by facilitating an illegal escape .
examples: His lieutenants hired a team of miners to help spring him.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , slang , rare ) To be free of imprisonment , especially by illegal escape .
( transitive , architecture , of arches ) To build , to form the initial curve of.
examples: They sprung an arch over the lintel.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , architecture , of arches , with "from" ) To extend , to curve .
examples: The arches spring from the front posts.

definitions.definition: ( transitive , nautical ) To turn a vessel using a spring attached to its anchor cable .
( transitive ) To pay or spend a certain sum , to yield .
( obsolete , intransitive , slang ) To raise an offered price .
( transitive , US , dialectal ) Alternative form of sprain .
( transitive , US , dialectal ) Alternative form of strain .
( intransitive , obsolete ) To act as a spring : to strongly rebound .
( transitive , rare ) To equip with springs , especially ( of vehicles ) to equip with a suspension .
( figurative , rare , obsolete ) to inspire , to motivate .
( ambitransitive ) To deform owing to excessive pressure , to become warped ; to intentionally deform in order to position and then straighten in place .
examples: A piece of timber sometimes springs in seasoning.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , UK , dialectal , chiefly of cows ) To swell with milk or pregnancy .
( transitive , of rattles , archaic ) To sound , to play .
( of animals ) To find or get enough food during springtime .

main_definition: ( intransitive ) To move or burst forth.

definitions.definition: To spend the springtime somewhere .

main_definition: ( intransitive ) To spend the springtime somewhere .
